citation.article-title: Reclassification of Halobacteroides halobius Z-7287 on the basis of phylogenetic analysis as a new species Halobacteroides elegans sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Halobacteroides elegans sp. nov.
Halobacteroides elegans (e.le.gans, adj. L.-thin, elegant)
Cells are thin, slightly curved rods, usually in pairs, short chains, or filaments 0.3-0.5 by 2-10 μm or longer.
In old cultures, spheroplasts are formed.
Spheroplasts are nonviable and the culture is difficult to store.
Cells are motile by means of peritrichous flagella.
The cell wall has a gram-negative structure.
The organism is spore-forming; spores are round, 0.12-0.15 μm in diameter, residing at the end of cells.
Multiplication occurs by unequal binary fission.
Eubacteria.
Colonies are lenslike with an even edge, yellowish, 0.5-1 mm in diameter.
Lysed colonies are transparent and viscous.
Cell paste is reddish-brown in color.
Obligately anaerobic.
Chemoorganotrophic, fermentative.
Utilizes a wide variety of carbohydrates, preferably sucrose, glucose, fructose, mannose, and trehalose.
Products of glucose fermentation are acetate, ethanol, H2, and CO2, Starch is hydrolyzed.
In the presence of elemental sulfur, produces hydrogen sulfide.
For anabolic needs, the sources of sulfur are organic sulfur-containing compounds rather than sulfide.
Methanethiol is utilized as the source of sulfur in the presence of leucine.
Requires yeast extract or a mixture of 20 amino acids.
Pantothenate is the only vitamin needed.
Obligately halophilic.
Optimal growth at 10-15%.
NaCl.
No growth at or under 5% NaCl.
Mesophilic.
Optimal temperature for growth is 40°C, maximal 47°C, and minimal 6°C.
pH range for growth is 6.5-8.0, with an optimum at pH 7.0.
The G+C content in DNA is 30.5 mol %.
Habitat: thalassic lagoons with variable salinity up to precipitation of halite.
The type strain Z-7287T (DSM 6639) and similar strain Z-7187 (DSM 6638) were isolated from a cyanobacterial mat in lagoons of Lake Sivash, Crimea.
